Appropriations to A&M College

| | | | | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | Apr 17 1871 | 75 000 | School Fund | Buildings | | Oct 2 1874 | 40 000 | General Revenue | " | | Feb 8 1875 | 32 000 | " " | " | | Jun 24 1876 | 40 000 | " " | " | | | $187,000 | appropriated before the College
was opened - | | | Spec. Sess. 1879 | 15,000 | University Fund | Library apparatus ag & Imple
ment & Mechanical Tools | | Def. Bill 1881 | 4 987.44 | General Revenue | To pay a debt incurred
in making improvements | | Appr. Bill 1881 | 15 000. | Univ. Fund | State Students | | Def " 1883 | 6 000 | General Revenue | " " | | " " 1883 | 800 | " " | To Settle Land Title | | Appr Bill 1883 | 30 000 | " " | Support & Maintenance
Improvements &c | | " " 1883 | 10 000 | University Fund | Do Do Do | | " " 1885 | 20 000 | General Revenue | Support & Maintenance | | " " 1885 | 10 000 | University Fund | " " | | Total | $298.787.44 | Covering a period from
1871 to 1887 - 16 years | |

$21 000 appropriated for State Students was of no
use to the College but went to the Students -

Deducting this amount you have Total
State appropriations from All Sources $277.787.44
For a period of 16 years

$187000 was expended before College was opened
Therefor $90 787.44 has been appropriated since the
College was inaugurated in 1876 more
than ten years an annual average of
only a little more than $900000

By referring to above it will be seen that
the total amount derived by College from
University Fund has been $50000
Or deducting amount for State Students $35000
An average for the ten sessions of only
$3500 benefit to the College from the
University Fund

**Here's my analysis of this financial record detailing appropriations to A&M College:** I'm looking at a record, likely a ledger, showing appropriations to "A & M College." It's divided into a table and a narrative section. ## Section 1: The Table | Date | Amount | Fund | Purpose | |---|---|---|---| | Apr 17 1871 | 75 000 | School Fund | Buildings | | Oct 2 1874 | 40 000 | General Revenue | " | | Feb 8 1875 | 32 000 | " | " | | Jun 24 1876 | 40 000 | " | " | | | $187,000 | | appropriated before the College was opened | | Spec. Sess. 1879 | 15 000 | University Fund | Library apparatus ag & Imple ment & Mechanical Tools | | Def. Bill 1881 | 4987.44 | General Revenue | To pay a debt incurred in making improvements | | Appr. Bill 1881 | 15000. | Univ. Fund | State Students | | Def " 1883 | 6000 | General Revenue | " | | " 1883 | 800 | " | To Settle Land Title | | Appr Bill 1883 | 30 000 | " | Support & Maintenance Improvements &c | | " 1883 | 10 000 | University Fund | Do Do Do | | " 1885 | 20 000 | General Revenue | Support & Maintenance | | " 1885 | 10 000 | University Fund | " | | | Total $298.787.44 | | Covering a period from 1871 to 1887 - 16 years | ## Section 2: The Narrative

$21000 appropriated for State Students was of no use to the College but went to the Students -

Deducting this amount you have Total State appropriations from All Sources $277.787.44
For a period of 16 years

$187000 was expended before College was opened
Therefore $90 787.44 has been appropriated since the College was inaugurated in 1876 more than ten years an annual average of only a little more than $900000

By referring to above it will be seen that the total amount derived by College from University Fund has been $50000
Or deducting amount for State Students $35000
An average for the ten sessions of only $3500 benefit to the College from the University Fund

Comparison between the University and
the A & M College

Comparison made to June 1886 because
the Report of Regents ends at that date-

Amounts Expended

| University | 1881 - June 1886 | 261788 | 44 | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | | Annual Average for 5 years | 52357 | 68 |
| A & M College | | (about) | | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | 1871- 86 15 years | From U.S. Endowment Interest | 150000 | | | | State appropriations | 285896 | 40 | | | Total from all sources - | 435896 | 40 | | | Annual Average from all sources | 29059 | 76 | | | " " State | 19059 | 76 | | | From University Fund 50,000 Ann. average | 3333 | 33 |

Or deducting amt for State Students

35000]

| we have for A & M College | | | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | Annual average | all sources | 27659 76 | | " " | State | 17659 76 | | " " | Univ Fund | 2333 33 |

It has been stated that the College has a much
larger plant than the University but in such
statements no account is taken of the fact
that the College has been established three
times as long as the University -
The fact that the College has more property than
the University only shows how economically its
affairs have been administered - for if we
deduct the amount used for State Students
we have as total amount which the A & M.
College has received from State for a period
of 15 years from 1871 to June 1886 $264896 40

The University has in five years from
1881- 1886 expended $261788.44

While the University has cost the State
nearly as much in 5 years as the College
has in 15 years, yet the College has
a much more valuable property for
the State than the University has

**Detailed Transcription and Analysis of Financial Comparison** Okay, here's what I've got. This is a transcription and analysis of a handwritten document comparing the financial situations of the "University" and the "A & M College". Based on my assessment, it seems to be a financial report or comparison, likely for some official use given the level of detail and the specific timeframes mentioned. I can see the structure right away. Here's a detailed transcription with my notes and annotations:

Comparison between the University and the A & M College
Comparison made to June 1886 because the Report of Regents ends at that date-

| | Amounts Expended | | |---|---|---| | University | 1881 - June 1886 | 261788 44 | | | Annual Average for 5 years | 52357 68 | | | | | |---|---|---| | A & M College | From U.S. Endowment Interest (about) | 150000 | | 1871 - 86 15 years | State appropriations | 285896 40 | | | Total from all sources - | 435896 40 | | | Annual Average from all sources | 29059 76 | | | " " State | 19059 76 | | | From University Fund 50,000 Ann. average | 3333 33 |

[Margin:]
Total
414896 40
264896 40
35000

Or deducting amt for State Students
we have for A & M College

| | | | |---|---|---| | | Annual average all sources | 27659 76 | | | " " State | 17659 76 | | | " " Univ Fund | 2333 33 |

It has been stated that the College has a much larger plant than the University but in such statements no account is taken of the fact that the College has been established three times as long as the University-

The fact that the College has more property than the University only shows how economically its affairs have been administered - for if we deduct the amount used for State Students we have as total amount which the A & M. College has received from State for a period of 15 years from 1871 to June 1886 $264896.40

The University has in five years from 1881-1886 expended $261788.44

While the University has cost the State nearly as much in 5 years as the College has in 15 years, yet the College has a much more valuable property for the State than the University has

So, what's happening here? It appears to be a comparative financial analysis. I've broken it down into sections: * **Header and Intro:** Sets the scene – comparing the two institutions, limiting the time frame. * **University Data:** Displays expenditures for the University over a five-year period. * **A & M College Data:** Gives figures for A & M College covering a much longer period. Notably, it sources funds. * **Deductions:** There's a deduction for "State Students," which adjusts the figures for A & M, and shows calculations made in the left margin. The deduction seems to have been based on 35000 or 1400/year for 15 years. * **Textual Analysis/Comparison:** The concluding paragraphs put these numbers into context. The writer is emphasizing that, while the University has spent almost as much as the College in a much shorter period, the College has more valuable assets. This is related to how long it has been established. Important notes, and observations: * **Handwriting:** It is cursive, somewhat messy, but generally legible. There are corrections and some numbers are overwritten. I've done my best with the numerals. * **Marginalia:** The margin notes seem to be important to the calculations, and I transcribed them. * **"Amounts Expended" note:** This line is inserted, suggesting it was added after the initial

3

In June 1886 the University Completed
its 3rd session The A & M College its
10th - The University had expended $261788.44
Average Cost per session since the Univ.
had been opened $ 87262.81

The A & M College expended to same date
from all sources $435896.40
An average per session 10 sessions of 43589.64
From State appropriations 285896.40
Average per session 28589.64
Or deducting Amt [illegible] State Students
The Average for ten sessions $ 26489.64

Compare these figures -
The College as a result had property valued at $228972.47
What has the University? not more than $100 000 worth
In three sessions the University [illegible]
from Univ fund 261788.44

In 15 years A & M C. had from
Univ fund exclusive of State
Students 35000.00
Or with amt for State Students 50000.00
This is surely a "small sized Grab"

Comparison of Expenses 1885-86 Session

| | A & M College | University | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | State Appr. | 17108.96 | $54928.82 | | U.S. Endowment | 11993.48 | | | | $ 29102.44 | |

The expense of A & M College was
a little more than 1/2 that of Univ.

**Image Analysis and Transcription: Financial Records of 1886** Alright, let's break this down. From what I can see, we've got some handwritten financial data here, probably from June 1886. It looks like a comparison between the "University" (likely the University of Texas, given the A&M context) and the Agricultural and Mechanical College (A&M). The handwriting is cursive and a bit rushed. The author appears to have written on lined ledger paper and made some corrections, which is useful in some ways, and distracting in others! We're dealing with things like sessions, expenditures, state appropriations, and endowments. The numbers are indented, probably indicating a tabular layout of sorts. Here's my transcription, line by line, aiming for accuracy while preserving the original layout and any quirks I spot:

3

In June 1886 the University Completed
its 3rd session The A & M College its
10th - The University had expended $261 788.44

Average Cost per session since the Univ.
had been opened $ 87262.81

The A & M College expended to same date
from all sources $435 896.40

An average per session 10 sessions of 43589.64
From State appropriations 285896.40
Average per session 28589.64

Or deducting Amt [illegible] State Students
The Average for ten sessions $ 26489.64

Compare these figures -
The College as a result had property valued at $228972.47
What has the University? not more than $100 000 worth
In three sessions the University [illegible]
from Univ fund 261788.44

In 15 years A & M C. had from
Univ fund exclusive of State
Students 35000.00
Or with amt for State Students 50000.00

This is surely a "small sized Grab"

Comparison of Expenses 1885-86 Session

| | A & M College | University | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | State Appr. | 17108.96 | $54928.82 | | U.S. Endowment | 11993.48 | | | | $ 29102.44 | |

The expense of A & M College was
a little more than 1/2 that of Univ.

4

Again All expenses of A&M C -
were for 85-86 as follows

| | | | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | State. Appr. | 17 108.96 | | | U.S. Endowment | 11 993 48 | | | Cash of maintaining | | | | Students paid by | | This last item is | | them | 17 176.19 | the amount that | | | $ 46 278.63 | the students pay for |

board washing fuel lights books medical attend
ance &c &c &c -

University for same session 54 928 82
Which does not include expenses of Students
The Cost of the University for Salaries
& running expenses was $ 8650 19
More than the total Cost expenses of
A&M College including all amounts
paid by Students for Board Books
Medical attendance &c &c &c -
If this latter these items were obtainable for the
University Students the difference would
be more emphatic. -

This will explain why the A&M has a larger property than the Univ.
It has not spent all its money in paying running expenses

Cost of Administration of the two institu-
tions for session 1885-86-

| University | A&M College | | :--- | :--- | | Salaries of Professors
& officers                 42 900 00 | 14 869.48
{ A&M Coll
about 1/3 Cost
of University | | Expenses Board
of Regents 2 years      $ 1812 00 | Expenses Bd of Directors
2 years          $ 449 03 |

A&M Board cost less than 1/4 that of the Univ Board
